reason:
UNDEFINED OBJECT: "MULTIPLICATIVE CHARACTER OF pi" IS A TYPE ERROR FOR n >= 2.

The node claims tau(pi, psi_Q) is nonzero "because the conductor of the additive character psi_Q exactly matches the conductor of the multiplicative character of pi." For GL_1, pi = chi IS a multiplicative character and this language is correct: chi : F* -> C* has a well-defined conductor, and the classical Gauss sum tau(chi, psi_Q) = int_{O*} chi(x) psi_Q(x) d*x is nonzero when cond(chi) = cond(psi_Q). This is Tate thesis.

For GL_n with n >= 2, pi is a REPRESENTATION (an infinite-dimensional vector space with a GL_n(F)-action), NOT a character. The phrase "the multiplicative character of pi" is undefined. Possible interpretations:

(A) The central character omega_pi : F* -> C*. But cond(omega_pi) != c(pi) in general. Example: pi = chi_1 x chi_2 on GL_2 with chi_1 of conductor p and chi_2 unramified. Then c(pi) = 1 but omega_pi = chi_1 * chi_2 has conductor depending on chi_1 * chi_2 (could be 0 if chi_2 = chi_1^{-1} on O*). The "conductor matching" fails.

(B) The det-character det(pi) = omega_pi^n. Same issue as (A).

(C) Some character extracted from the K-type theory of pi. Not standard and never defined.

For GL_n (n >= 2), the analog of the GL_1 Gauss sum nonvanishing is the nonvanishing of the Godement-Jacquet epsilon factor epsilon(s, pi, psi). But epsilon(s, pi, psi) is ALWAYS a nonzero constant times a power of q^{-s}, regardless of conductor matching. The "conductor matching" argument is specific to the GL_1 situation and does not generalize as the node implies.

The node commits a type error by treating an n^2-dimensional representation as if it were a one-dimensional character, then applying a GL_1 result (conductor-matched Gauss sum nonvanishing) to a categorically different mathematical object.
